first several lines of output are shown for the first gene (AKT1) in the worked example (see Step 17).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"830ua","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"lr7g","text":"NM_001014432.fa","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2ls6d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"auqhp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"code_insert","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"faaak","text":"\u003eprobe_1_index_264_MinTm_55","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7fhaf","text":"tttgacccaggctggctcggccttccctaagc","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"38n0a","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5m936","text":"\u003eprobe_2_index_317_MinTm_55","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"259h8","text":"cctctgatgcaccagctgacaggctgcctcct","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6hnmu","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7uvvg","text":"\u003eprobe_3_index_425_MinTm_55","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ffpdl","text":"caaccctccttcacaatagccacgtcgctcat","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"b3vql","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"13pvq","text":"...","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bq4mr","text":"Typical Use and Modifying Parameters to Increase Number of Homology Regions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":75}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"be4j0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3rhgd","text":"In typical usage, the script will be run once, with the same high Tm threshold for all genes to generate draft candidate regions for all genes. For specific genes of interest where too few homology regions were generated, a new genelist will be constructed containing solely those genes requiring further optimization, and the script will be rerun with modified parameters. This process is iterated until enough candidate regions have been generated for all genes in the original genelist.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dtvfi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"85kvl","text":"Several parameters can be modified to increase the number of binding regions. These include:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"93kug","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a8cu4","text":"Adjusting the minimum Tm for individual genes: a decrease from 55 to 53 or 51 can potentially identify more homology regions.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ef1d5","text":"Increasing the maximum acceptable Tm range (MAX_TM_SEPARATION) can also potentially identify more homology regions. Together with (1), these two parameters are the most commonly modified parameters.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c13mn","text":"Increasing the range of acceptable GC content (GC_RANGE). ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5liao","text":"Decreasing the E value threshold (E_VALUE), can allow for more non-specific (lower E value) hits to be tolerated. ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1g424","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7nefq","text":"On adjusting the E value threshold: the E value threshold is the maximum E value for hits returned by BLAST. Hits with higher E values are ignored for further consideration for elimination of the candidate binding region. Lowering the E value threshold allows for more non-specific (E values above the threshold) hits to be tolerated. For example, consider a candidate sequence with two hits, one self-hit in the original gene of interest with E value=1e-8, and an off-target partial homology match with E value=0.002. If the E value threshold is set to E_VALUE=0.05, the off-target hit will be considered for further exclusion criteria. However, if the E value is lowered to E_VALUE=0.001, the off-target hit will no longer be considered for further exclusion, and the sequence may be accepted as a homology sequence.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8eg7j","text":"[Optional] Validating Homology Regions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":38}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4bln9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bhaa0","text":"This is an optional step to validate the homology regions identified in the previous steps. This validation step consists of re-BLASTing the homology regions primarily to confirm that there are no off-target hits resulting from the process by which self-hits and pseudogene hits are tolerated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7apof","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8d3uu","text":"When searching for homology regions in a gene, hits in splice variants, pseudogenes, and non-coding variants of that transcript should be tolerated. This is implemented by searching the gene names of hits to ensure they start with the gene symbol of the gene of interest. For example, a hit in the KRT17 pseudogene KRT17P1 would be tolerated, as the gene symbol \"KRT17P1\" begins with \"KRT17\". ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"doot8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dl1vr","text":"However, this may potentially create artifacts. As an example, when designing probes for CD4, there may potentially be a hit in CD44. Since \"CD44\" begins with \"CD4\", the hit would be tolerated, and the homology region could be accepted. The output of this script, with manual review, corrects for this potential issue.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"90i89","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6tkqk","text":"To identify these events and exclude them if necessary, the previously found homology regions are BLASTed again under the same search criteria used previously, except without gene symbol/accession number filtering. Hits are collected, and the results are saved to a spreadsheet for manual verification. If problematic sequences are identified, they can be individually removed from the FASTA files containing the homology regions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3jn86","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1ltiq","text":"The script for this step is Targeted_ExSeq_ProbeGeneration_Validate_Homology_Regions.m. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4navq","text":"Parameters Requiring User Input","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":31}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"42g8t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8sre2","text":"There are four parameters that require user input.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aptv6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9ukdp","text":"genelist_spreadsheet, the location/filename of the genelist.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3if9j","text":"refseq_database, the location/filename of the .fna file generated previously. This filename should include the .fna extension.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4h7ql","text":"homology_regions_input, the name of the directory (created by the previous script) where homology regions are  saved.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3i0ie","text":"output_filename, the filename of the spreadsheet where the summary of the homology region validation will be saved.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8f9sa","text":"Optional Parameters to Set","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cqtvb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1oreh","text":"There are four parameters that can optionally be changed. They are the same as the parameters defined previously in Step 9.2. They are listed below, along with their default values. The parameters are all contained within the params struct.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8b72u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1p9ej","text":"These values should be set to the same values used for the prior search.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cqafl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dm0j6","text":"HOMOLOGY_LENGTH = 32","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9aqnn","text":"E_VALUE = 0.05","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d7e3c","text":"BLAST_HOMOLOGY_MIN_LENGTH_CUTOFF = 13","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"56ui1","text":"BLAST_HOMOLOGY_LIGATION_JUNCTION_MIN_OVERLAP_CUTOFF = 4","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b2sae","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4o65g","text":"Output and Interpretation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2kqsn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bpi35","text":"The output spreadsheet is saved to the file indicated by the parameter output_filename. This spreadsheet contains one row for every homology region generated by the previous script. The first two columns of the spreadsheet list the gene symbol and the homology region sequence. The third column onwards lists the gene symbols for the BLAST hits that pass filtering. Self-hits are included here, as no gene symbol filtering is performed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cq0p5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ba0fo","text":"An example excerpt of the output for Human KRT17 from the worked example (see Step 17) is shown in Table 2. There are hits in KRT17 pseudogenes for all of the homology sequences identified, which are tolerated for this application.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":99,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ej4l0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bpi9b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"62jl6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"9pvgl","text":"The user should look through the results and ensure that hits to other transcripts (if any) are tolerable (i.e. are hits in pseudogenes or very closely related homologs). If a hit is unacceptable, that homology region should be removed from the relevant FASTA file in the output of the previous script.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"","data":{"cellsMeta":[],"colTitles":["","","","",""],"colWidths":["68","241","64","77","73.18179321289062"],"data":[["KRT17","gcaggcacacaggagaagggctggagaggaga","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","gagccaaagctgtagcagctggagtagctgct","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","tctcacctccagccagcagcccatcaacaccc","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","ggctgtgaggatcttgttctgcagctcctcaa","KRT17","KRT17P1",""],["KRT17","ctgcagctctatctccaaggcctgcatggtgc","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","tgtctccgccaggttgccctccagggatgctt","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","caccggttctttcttgtactgagtcaggtggg","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","tggacctcttccacaatggtacgcacctgacg","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","caaggaagcatggggaagggactgaagcaggg","KRT17","KRT17P1","\u0000"]],"guid":"7C57A200C8F611EB9A8213CF2B68D30D","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"mrvv","text":"Table 2. Excerpt of output for KRT17 example. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mergeCells":[],"printData":[["KRT17","gcaggcacacaggagaagggctggagaggaga","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","gagccaaagctgtagcagctggagtagctgct","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","tctcacctccagccagcagcccatcaacaccc","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","ggctgtgaggatcttgttctgcagctcctcaa","KRT17","KRT17P1",""],["KRT17","ctgcagctctatctccaaggcctgcatggtgc","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","tgtctccgccaggttgccctccagggatgctt","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","caccggttctttcttgtactgagtcaggtggg","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","tggacctcttccacaatggtacgcacctgacg","KRT17","KRT17P1","KRT17P2"],["KRT17","caaggaagcatggggaagggactgaagcaggg","KRT17","KRT17P1","\u0000"]],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23,23]}}}}

steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"37vn0","text":"Overview of Steps","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f72mg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2cfh8","text":"In the previous script, sequences for the homology regions H1/H2 in the padlock probe (Fig. 1A) were identified.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":87,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6adar","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6f68d","text":"In this section, three tasks are accomplished: (1) converting the logical barcode sequences to nucleotide sequences that can be read out with the SOLiD and Illumina chemistries (corresponding to SOLiD BC and Illumina BC in Fig. 1A); (2) assembly of the homology regions, barcode sequences, and fixed RCA/Seq primer site into the final padlock probe sequences (as in Fig. 1A); and (3) exporting the padlock probe sequences in spreadsheet form.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":223,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":366,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bemb6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dhpdu","text":"This is implemented in the MATLAB script Targeted_ExSeq_ProbeGeneration_Assembly.m.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8n7o0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"129b8","text":"This script assumes the existence of a genelist spreadsheet, and that the first script to generate homology regions has been run.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"er71","text":"Mapping Logical Barcodes to Nucleotide Barcodes -- Overview","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":59}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7dcja","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"q7n7","text":"As described previously, barcodes are designed in a logical barcode space, to allow for the barcode design to be independent of the barcode implementation, which depends on the sequencing chemistry. The barcode readout occurs after rolling circle amplification on the RCA product, which is the reverse complement of the padlock probe sequence (Fig. 1A).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":344,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ba7jb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e1ij7","text":"Here, the logical barcodes generated in Step 3 are converted to specific nucleotide sequences for readout with the Illumina and SOLiD sequencing chemistries. Technical details on this conversion are provided in the following substeps. An overview of the relationship between the logical barcodes and nucleotides is provided in Fig. 1B, with the specific structure of the barcodes implemented here shown in Fig. 1C.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":327,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":406,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9mrs1","text":"Technical Note: Mapping Logical Barcodes to Nucleotide Sequences -- Illumina Chemistry","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":86}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"es17f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9tfcf","text":"In this step, the technical details of the mapping between logical barcodes and nucleotide sequences for readout with the Illumina chemistry are discussed. In short, each logical barcode position directly corresponds to a specific nucleotide position in the barcode sequence on the padlock probe, and the identity of that sequence is determined by the mapping, discussed below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"asnnn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4m9qk","text":"Barcode sequence amplification: the Illumina barcode sequence is located 3' to the RCA primer binding site on the padlock probe (Fig. 1A). After rolling circle amplification, the reverse complement of the original Illumina barcode sequence is located 5' to the sequencing primer binding site (Fig. 1A, 1D). Note that the sequencing primer binding site is the reverse complement of the RCA primer binding site. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":129,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":293,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4o0vi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8comd","text":"Barcode sequencing with Illumina chemistry: after hybridizing the sequencing primer to the RCA amplicon, sequencing can proceed. Fluorophore-labeled nucleotides are sequentially added, imaged, and then cleaved using the Illumina chemistry. This allows the barcode sequence to be read out, base by base, using sequencing by synthesis. This is shown schematically in Fig. 1F for the 7-base barcode structure shown in Fig. 1C. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":365,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":415,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5s29k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2nu7v","text":"An example of this process is shown in Fig. 1D. The top strand is the RCA product, with the barcode template bases GATC (from 5' to 3'). The sequencing primer is shown as the bottom strand, and four consecutive rounds of in situ sequencing are shown, interrogating C, T, A, G in that order, with added bases of G, A, T, and C. The original sequence on the padlock probe was the reverse complement of GATC, which in this case is GATC. The decoded logical barcode is 2031. We note that the barcode sequence on the padlock probe is also the sequence of the nucleotides that are sequentially added during the sequencing by synthesis process.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":39,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":221,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4i7ml","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ekj6v","text":"Barcode construction: the translation of a logical barcode to a nucleotide sequence is a one-to-one mapping from logical values to nucleotides specified by the table in Fig. 1B. For the specific barcode architecture used in this protocol (see Step 4), this is shown in the colors shared between Fig. 1C and Fig. 1F for specific barcode positions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":169,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":295,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":307,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ce2e3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7n9bf","text":"There are three columns in Fig. 1B that are relevant for the Illumina chemistry: the logical barcode, Illumina color, and Illumina template base. The first mapping is between the logical barcode value and the template base, which is the base in the RCA product. The complement of this base is the actual base in the barcode sequence in the padlock probe and is also the added base (as described above). That is, a logical value of '2' corresponds to a template base of 'C', and a padlock and added base of 'G'. The second mapping is between the template base and the color. This is determined by the sequencing chemistry. This protocol uses the MiSeq 4-color chemistry from Illumina (described in more detail in the in situ sequencing protocol).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":27,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":716,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ed21v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2bkdk","text":"To implement the translation, the logical barcode is translated base by base to the nucleotide sequence using the specified mapping. The translated nucleotide sequence is placed 3' to the RCA primer binding site on the padlock probe. Using the standard parameters, this translation process is equivalent to a direct replacement of the logical bases {0, 1, 2, 3} with the nucleotide bases {'A', 'C', 'G', 'T'}.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"s07i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6tcea","text":"As an example, the logical barcode 1020301 is translated into CAGATAC on the padlock probe, corresponding to GTATCTG on the RCA product. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2579d","text":"Technical Note: Mapping Logical Barcodes to Nucleotide Sequences -- SOLiD Chemistry","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":83}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a06ub","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1tand","text":"In this step, the technical details of the mapping between logical barcodes and nucleotide sequences for readout with the SOLiD chemistry are discussed. The key difference between the Illumina sequencing chemistry and the SOLiD sequencing chemistry is that SOLiD interrogates dibase pairs of nucleotides. Because these dibases can also be interrogated in a partly flexible order, additional constraints on the barcode design are necessary to generate the SOLiD barcodes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"epb1o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bspml","text":"Barcode sequence amplification: the SOLiD barcode sequence is located 5' to the RCA primer binding site on the padlock probe (Fig. 1A). After rolling circle amplification, the reverse complement of the original SOLiD barcode sequence is located 3' to the sequencing primer binding site. Note that the sequencing primer binding site is the reverse complement of the RCA primer binding site.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":126,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e7h57","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8gjed","text":"Barcode sequencing with SOLiD chemistry: to interrogate different dibase positions, SOLiD sequencing uses multiple offset sequencing primers. The sequencing primers are called SeqN to SeqN-4, where the number indicates the number of bases that the primer is recessed from the start of the SOLiD barcode.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bd8q4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9coma","text":"SOLiD sequencing proceeds as follows. (1) One of these sequencing primers is hybridized to the amplicons. (2) The first ligation of SOLiD sequencing oligos is performed. The ligation mix contains all SOLiD sequencing oligos. The oligo that is ligated to the growing sequencing product is the one that correctly interrogates the dibase on the template strand that is adjacent to the growing sequencing product. (3) As the the SOLiD oligos are fluorophore-labeled, imaging is performed. Each amplicon is detected in one (of four) colors. (4) A cleavage step is then performed, which cleaves the last three nucleotides off the 5' end of the SOLiD oligo, including the linkage to the fluorophore. The cleavage also reveals a 5' phosphate on the sequencing product, which is used for the next ligation. (5) Further cycles of ligation-imaging-cleavage are performed. (6) At the end of sequencing on one primer, the sequencing product is stripped, and a sequencing primer with a different offset is hybridized to the amplicons. This process is repeated for each sequencing primer. The net result of this process is that information about the dibases in the sample is read out. The order of this readout is in a different order from the order of the dibases within the barcode sequence. Each round of imaging (i.e. detected dibase) corresponds to one round from the barcode.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9q9le","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cglcc","text":"An example of the sequencing process is shown schematically in Fig. 1E. This figure shows the hybridization of the SeqN-1 primer (as the end of the primer is recessed by one base relative to the start of the barcode sequence), followed by two ligations on the primer. In the first ligation, the template bases are 5' A, C 3', matched by 5' G, T 3' on the seq oligo. The oligo is then cleaved, and the second ligation is performed. On the second ligation, the template bases are 5' G, C 3', matched by 5' G, C 3' on the seq oligo. This process will then be repeated on the other sequencing primers: SeqN, and SeqN-2 to SeqN-4. Note that for SeqN-2 to SeqN-4, the first ligation does not need to be imaged, since this ligation occurs within the primer sequence and is detecting known dibases in the template.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":63,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8gop","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7rkjr","text":"The interrogated dibases of the sequencing process are summarized in Table 3. For targeted ExSeq under the constraints outlined in the abstract (for the scheme in Fig. 1C and Fig. 1G), we do not need to consider ligations beyond ligation 2.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":69,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":163,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":175,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cl9h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"9c8mt","text":"Note that the sequencing on different primers is an independent process, and that primers can be sequenced in any order.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"50i2b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e1keo","text":"Barcode construction: the translation of a logical barcode to a nucleotide sequence depends on the order of how interrogated dibases correspond to bases in the barcode. We refer to this order as the \"barcode specification\". Once the specification is set, the nucleotide sequences can be determined. Fig. 1B shows the mapping between logical barcodes, colors, and template dibases. The specific barcode architecture used in this protocol (see Step 4) is shown in Fig. 1C, and is implemented as shown in Fig. 1G (note that the barcode colors are shared across these figures). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":299,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":462,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":502,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6e2qe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e6fnr","text":"Setting the barcode specification: the barcode specification defines which dibases (and associated sequencing primers/ligation positions) correspond to which positions of the logical barcode. In this protocol, the barcode structure in Fig. 1C  is implemented using the specification shown in Fig. 1G.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":235,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":292,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"616gl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fntl1","text":"Explicitly, the barcode specification states: BC1 (SeqN-1, Ligation 1); BC2 (SeqN-1, Ligation 2); BC3 (SeqN, Ligation 1); BC4 (SeqN, Ligation 2); BC5 (SeqN-2, Ligation 2); BC6 (SeqN-3, Ligation 2); BC7 (SeqN-4, Ligation 2). BCx are the positions in the logical barcode, and the sequencing specifications in parentheses define the dibase corresponding to that logical barcode value. This is shown graphically in Fig. 1C and Fig. 1G. Corresponding logical barcode positions in Fig. 1C and sequencing rounds in Fig. 1G are shown in the same color. The dibases interrogated are colored with black circles. \"Silent\" ligations that are performed but not imaged are shown with dashed lines.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":411,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":423,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":475,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":508,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8cjq8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fkfne","text":"The formal barcode specification is defined as shown in Table 4. The rows and columns define the sequencing primer and ligation number, and the value is the logical barcode position, i.e. SeqN-2, Ligation 2 is logical barcode position 5.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":56,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9kh41","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"f5bpn","text":"Note that this barcode specification determines the total length of the oligonucleotide barcode, since the highest barcode position in Table 3 for any of the ligations specified in Table 4 is 7 (corresponding to the 6,7 dibase for SeqN, Ligation 2). Thus, the total oligonucleotide length of the SOLiD barcode is 7 bases.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":135,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":181,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"703vr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"efsad","text":"The advantage of this scheme is that it allows the embedded four round, HD2 barcode to be read out in four rounds of SOLiD sequencing, without requiring the use of any silent ligations, and only requiring the use of two sequencing primers. In addition, the sequencing of the full barcode can be performed linearly; by using the primers SeqN-1, SeqN, SeqN-2, SeqN-3, and SeqN-4 in that order, the barcode can be read out from BC1 to BC7 in order, without requiring any data rounds to be shuffled.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2rc79","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7k25k","text":"An alternative barcode specification would be to directly interrogate the barcode sequence from left to right, where each BCx corresponds to the x-1,x nucleotide dibase. Explicitly: BC1 is the 0,1 dibase (SeqN-1, Ligation 1); BC2 is the 1,2 dibase (SeqN, Ligation 1); BC3 is the 2,3 dibase (SeqN-4, Ligation 2); BC4 is the 3,4 dibase (SeqN-3, Ligation 2); BC5 is the 4,5 dibase (SeqN-2, Ligation 2); BC6 is the 5,6 dibase (SeqN-1, Ligation 2); and BC7 is the 6,7 dibase (SeqN, Ligation 2). This barcode structure is conceptually simpler, but requires additional silent ligations to read out the embedded length 4, HD2 embedded barcode library, and requires additional data shuffling (since, for example, the two ligations on SeqN will be performed sequentially, but correspond to logical barcode BC2 and BC7).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b3vec","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f3bii","text":"The formal specification for this scheme is shown in Table 5.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":53,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"enh61","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"8s6eu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8vbq0","text":"Translating the order to nucleotides: the barcode specification and the SOLiD logical barcode to nucleotide mapping (Fig. 1B) are used to construct the nucleotide sequence. There are three columns in Fig. 1B that are relevant for SOLiD sequencing: the logical barcode, the the color, and the table showing the dibase/color relationship. The first mapping is between the logical barcode values and the colors. This relates the logical barcode to the expected color during imaging, where blue through red correspond to the four SOLiD sequencing dyes from lowest to highest excitation wavelength.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":117,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":200,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4j6ht","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"25e7i","text":"The second mapping is between the template bases and colors, shown in the dibase nucleotide to color table. The first base of the dibase (from 5' to 3' on the template) determines the row, and the second base determines the column. For example, the template dibase 5' A, C 3' (from Fig. 1E) is row 1, column 2, which is green, corresponding to a logical barcode value of 1.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":282,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"852cp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3a7v5","text":"The challenge with SOLiD barcode construction is that each logical barcode value could correspond to multiple dibase nucleotides. For example, a logical barcode value of 2 (orange) could correspond to template dibases of: {AG, CT, GA, TC}. To disambiguate between these possibilities, information about the adjacent dibases (that share one nucleotide with the current dibase) is needed. If every nucleotide in the barcode is included in two dibases (with the exception of the terminal barcode nucleotide (i.e. position 7 here), then the barcode is fully specified, and can be constructed by considering each dibase sequentially. The construction begins by considering the 0,1 dibase, which contains a base from the sequencing primer in position 0, which fixes the value of the base in position 1. Consideration of the 1,2 dibase now has a fixed value in position 1, which specifies the value of the base in position 2. This process is repeated to construct the complete barcode sequence. Again, the key coverage constraint is that every base in the barcode except the final base is included in two dibases.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5k2qp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c720m","text":"Modifiability: this section focuses on the length 7, HD3 barcode library with embedded length 4, HD2 library (as shown in Fig. 1C and Fig. 1G), but the approach is flexible for different barcode specifications, as long as the barcode coverage constraint is satisfied.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":122,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":134,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dbr33","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cetqc","text":"To summarize, a logical barcode can be translated to a SOLiD nucleotide barcode if a SOLiD barcoding specification is defined, and if each nucleotide in the barcode (except the final base) is included in two dibases in the barcoding specification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"tables","mutability":"","data":{"cellsMeta":{"A_2":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_3":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_4":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_5":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_6":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"B_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"C_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"}},"colTitles":["","",""],"colWidths":[100,"127.66667175292969","129"],"data":[["","Bases interrogated by ligation 1","Bases interrogated by ligation 2"],["SeqN","1,2","6,7"],["SeqN-1","0,1","5,6"],["SeqN-2","not imaged","4, 5"],["SeqN-3","not imaged","3, 4"],["SeqN-4","not imaged","2, 3"]],"guid":"7325DB30C98B11EB9897DDD980ECC019","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"aleal","text":"Table 3. Summary of barcode bases interrogated using SOLiD sequencing on SeqN to SeqN-4 sequencing primers.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mergeCells":[],"printData":[["","Bases interrogated by ligation 1","Bases interrogated by ligation 2"],["SeqN","1,2","6,7"],["SeqN-1","0,1","5,6"],["SeqN-2","not imaged","4, 5"],["SeqN-3","not imaged","3, 4"],["SeqN-4","not imaged","2, 3"]],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23,23]}},"1":{"type":"tables","mutability":"","data":{"cellsMeta":{"A_2":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_3":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_4":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_5":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"A_6":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"B_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"},"C_1":{"className":"_dt-bold"}},"colTitles":["","",""],"colWidths":[100,100,100],"data":[["","Ligation 1","Ligation 2"],["SeqN","3","4"],["SeqN-1","1","2"],["SeqN-2","not detected","5"],["SeqN-3","not detected","6"],["SeqN-4","not detected","7"]],"guid":"C7103910CDA111EB82B7C115EC98C081","isJexcelDataFormat":true,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":7,"offset":60,"style":"bold"}],"key":"st3c","text":"Table 4. steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"jhaa","text":"Running Probe Assembly Script","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"62b75","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bjd2c","text":"Targeted_ExSeq_ProbeGeneration_Assembly.m assembles the final probe sequences and formats them in several output formats.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bqkjo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9mdng","text":"Briefly, the assembly scripts loops through each gene, generates SOLiD and Illumina nucleotide sequences for that gene's logical barcode, then assembles the final probe sequences, including 5' phosphorylation. The data is output in three spreadsheets for export, further explained in Step 14.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bskqt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8vhk6","text":"Prerequisites: the script requires a genelist spreadsheet and a directory with homology regions (from the first script).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ceot4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3ka7m","text":"Parameters are specified in several sections in the script.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"996h9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1fmka","text":"Section 1 covers the standard set of simple parameters -- the required parameters for reading/writing out files and basic metadata, along with optional parameters for changing aspects of the padlock probes and export formats.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cgupa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"36kjh","text":"Section 2 covers advanced parameters that define the mapping between logical barcodes and the Illumina and SOLiD sequencing chemistries. Most users will not need to change these parameters.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"24aji","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ep5d0","text":"Section 3 covers parameters that determine the SOLiD barcoding specification. Most users will not need to change these parameters, as the scheme in Fig. 1G is implemented as shown. For alternative barcoding schemes, this section will need to be modified.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":148,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

generation).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"47pq8","text":"metadata, a string describing the nature of the probe set, i.e. 'Cancer' steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"9ibna","text":"Optional Parameters to Set -- Section 1","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":39}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2l5ij","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cjcmh","text":"In section 1, there are five optional parameters to modify. Most users will not need to modify these parameters. All of these parameters are saved in the params struct.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ccmea","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dv5ho","text":"RCA_PRIMER_BINDING_SITE= 'TCTCGGGAACGCTGAAGACGGC', the sequence on the padlock probe backbone that the RCA primer hybridizes to. The default sequence is a modified version of the universal primer binding sequence from FISSEQ to increase its Tm.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c66s5","text":"SPACER_SEQUENCE = 'AAA', the spacer between each homology region arm and the SOLiD/Illumina barcode sequences. The length of this spacer is set so that the total length of the padlock probe is equal to 2*n+10, where n is the length of the homology region. Under the standard design, n = 32 nt, so 2*n+10 = 74 nt.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fu3jt","text":"MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROBES = 16, the maximum number of padlock probes to generate per gene. A constraint for exporting the probes is that PLATE_NUM_ROWS must be a divisor of MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROBES.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bnjed","text":"PLATE_NUM_ROWS = 8, standard geometry for 96-well plate, used for exporting probes.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"a7e7f","text":"PLATE_NUM_COLS = 12, standard geometry for 96-well plate, used for exporting probes.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cm3cb","text":"Optional Advanced Sequencing Chemistry Parameters to Set -- Section 2","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":69}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7279j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d944h","text":"In section 2, there are four parameters that could optionally be modified to change the mapping between logical bases and nucleotide sequences. The default values match those shown in Fig. 1B, and can be changed if desired.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":184,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5jip1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3kftp","text":"ILLUMINA_MAP_LOGICAL = {'0', '1', '2', '3'}, the acceptable logical barcode values to be translated to nucleotides for the Illumina chemistry.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6q2nu","text":"ILLUMINA_MAP_TEMPLATE = {'T', 'G', 'C', 'A'}, the corresponding nucleotides for the logical barcodes on the sequencing template (amplicon).","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"12s9a","text":"SOLID_NUCLEOTIDE_KEYS = {'A'; 'C'; 'G'; 'T'}, the nucleotides defining the row/columns of the SOLID_DIBASE_MATRIX.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1fsd","text":"SOLID_DIBASE_MATRIX = [[0, 1, 2, 3]; [1, 0, 3, 2]; [2, 3, 0, 1]; [3, 2, 1, 0]], the standard SOLiD sequencing matrix mapping between nucleotides and dibases.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1odqf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cjd6j","text":"The key computed parameters stored in the params struct are ILLUMINA_MAP, SOLID_DIBASE_ENCODING_SPECIFICATION, and SOLID_LOGICAL2DIBASE.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"83quo","text":"SOLiD Barcoding Specification Parameters -- Section 3","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":53}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"90pp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e5bb2","text":"In section 3, the SOLiD barcode specification is set. Optional parameters can be modified to change the specification. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"abkh1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9u82p","text":"The default specification is for the standard sequencing scheme (Table 4). Most users will not need to change any of these values.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":65,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"le48","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7f3sk","text":"There is one parameter (in the params struct) that needs to be defined before defining the SOLiD barcode specification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c28ms","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"277nh","text":"MAX_NUM_LIGATIONS = 2, the maximum number of ligations on a single primer required for this barcoding scheme.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f7br4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c9qnd","text":"The barcode specification can then be defined. The specification is structured in the form of a MATLAB table, with row names 'SeqN', 'SeqN-1', .... , 'SeqN-4' and column names 'Ligation_1', ... 'Ligation_MAX_NUM_LIGATIONS'. The specification is defined by creating the table with all NaN entries, then individually defining the logical barcode position for each sequencing primer and ligation by setting the value of that entry in the table to the logical barcode position, as shown in Table 4. Silent ligations remain NaN values.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":486,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7v9jl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8nsaj","text":"Two barcoding specifications are defined in this section: (1) the standard barcode specification (Fig. 1G and Table 4) as T_barcode_specification_embedded_len4_HD2; and (2) the alternative barcode specification (Table 5) as T_barcode_specification_consecutive_bases. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":98,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":110,"length":7},{"style":"bold","offset":212,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9816r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"181c7","text":"The final two variables select the sequencing scheme used, and provide additional metadata.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4jnp8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5aoes","text":"T_selected_barcode_specification = T_barcode_specification_embedded_len4_HD2, this variable selects the barcode specification used in the probe assembly. The default is to select the standard barcode specification.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8e7i8","text":"solid_barcode_descriptor = 'embedded_len4', this character array adds additional metadata describing the SOLiD barcode specification to the full probe name.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1cie3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"58iad","text":"More complex changes to the SOLiD barcoding scheme will require significant edits to this section.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Generation of Barcode Sequences, Probe Assembly, and Export
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"fa2vi","text":"Script Output ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8i1j1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b5n80","text":"This script outputs three spreadsheets that are saved in the directory specified by output_directory.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f12r6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"61eqv","text":"The first output spreadsheet (named as defined by all_probes_output_filename) lists all of the generated probes in a single spreadsheet. This spreadsheet has four columns: (1) gene symbol; (2) full probe name (containing a description of the species, metadata, date of generation, gene symbol, barcode, SOLiD barcoding scheme, and probe number); (3) an abbreviated probe name (containing the species, metadata, barcode, and probe number); and (4) padlock probe oligonucleotide sequence. Each gene has MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROBES rows in the spreadsheet; if the script was not able to generate MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROBES probes, empty rows are inserted at the appropriate positions.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"c2pgs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"epp3d","text":"The second output spreadsheet (named as defined by probes_output_by_sheets_filename) lists all of the generated probes, formatted into multiple sheets, where each sheet contains the probes in one plate. This spreadsheet can be directly uploaded to IDT through their plate upload interface for ordering. The columns of each sheet are Well Position, Name, and Sequence. The well position specifies the position in the plate for the oligo with the listed sequence.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1q0v6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bp79r","text":"The third output spreadsheet (named as defined by plate_map_for_pooling_filename) contains multiple sheets, one for each plate. The sheets are maps of the individual plates, where the gene symbol is listed in the corresponding wells containing probes for that gene. This serves as a visual map of the plates during probe pooling in step 16.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fjqe3","text":"Ordering Probes","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"emebb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7ccvs","text":"Padlock probes can be ordered from any major DNA oligonucleotide synthesis company (i.e. IDT, Eurofins Genomics, others). Note that the phosphorylation modification code inserted in the previous section may be different between companies (i.e. /5Phos/ for IDT; [PHO] for Eurofins).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"deu19","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"tqla","text":"Typical orders are in a 96-well plate format at 25 nmol scale, full-yield, shipped wet in RNAse-free water in V-bottom plates at 200 uM concentration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d2de1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4nj1j","text":"The output plates by sheets spreadsheet from Step 14 can be directly used to upload the sequence information to the IDT website. Go to Products \u0026 Services -\u003e DNA \u0026 RNA -\u003e Custom DNA Oligos -\u003e DNA oligos (Order now) -\u003e Select Plates -\u003e 25 nmol, 96 well plate. Click on upload plates, and upload the spreadsheet. Set the options listed in the previous paragraph, and apply properties to all plates in the order.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f17ie","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2458d","text":"When ordering through IDT, the minimum number of occupied wells per 96-well plate is 24 wells. If a plate does not have 24 padlock probes, additional sequences need to be added to other wells to reach that number of utilized wells. These additional sequences do not need to be padlock probes -- they just have to be oligo sequences that meet the minimum sequence length.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"egg56","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9e9to","text":"We recommend discussing large orders for multiple plates with a representative from the company, which may significantly reduce the cost (especially for the 5' phosphorylation modification).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1qvqr","text":"Preparing Pooled Probe Library","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2a906","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dapv9","text":"In this step, probes are pooled together to prepare the pooled probe library, used in the Targeted ExSeq Library Preparation protocol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2e39l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1nmkn","text":"Before starting, clean the bench by wiping down surfaces and pipettes with 70% ethanol, followed by RNAseZap.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9b1c0","text":"Preparation of Plates for Pooling","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5q9fn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9r4bm","text":"Thaw 96-well plates of probes at   until completely thawed (typically 15 to 30 minutes).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":33,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"7pdom","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4ih67","text":"Briefly spin down plates in centrifuge to at least 100x g to pull fluid to the bottom of the wells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8sq9s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4qrse","text":"Carefully remove plates from the centrifuge and proceed to preparing individual probe pools.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"B02D1AB0CA8111EB9897DDD980ECC019","id":"47733","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"","unit":32}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d2bm5","text":"Preparation of Individual Probe Pools","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4hesd","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cnih9","text":"In this step, individual probe pools for each transcript of interest in the library are prepared.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ejono","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"44up","text":"Carefully open the rubber seal for one plate at a time. Avoid any motions that may cause splashes between wells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b5442","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4naek","text":"Using the exported plate map spreadsheet as a guide (from Step 14), pool the entire volume of all padlock probes for a transcript into a single 2 mL microcentrifuge tube to form the individual probe pool for that transcript. Repeat for all transcripts in the library across all plates. The pooling can be performed with an ordinary pipette.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f8ac","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7rauf","text":"The per-probe concentration of each padlock probe in the individual gene pool is the probe concentration that the plates were ordered at, divided by the number of probes in the individual gene pool (i.e. for 200 μM plates and 16 probes for the current gene, the per-probe concentration in the individual probe pool is 200 μM/16 = 12.5 μM).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"apvg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2e1ov","text":"After preparing all the probe pools, vortex the tubes and spin them down on a benchtop centrifuge, then either proceed to preparing the pooled probe library, or freeze the individual probe pools down at  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":203,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"a9kp2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dajou","text":"Note: there is some variation in probe yields between wells in the plate. These effects are relatively minor (~20% variation) and we assume that they do not affect the downstream results with targeted ExSeq. A more precise approach to pooling the probes would be to use a multichannel pipette to pull the same volume from each well, pool them together in a reservoir, and then transfer to a microcentrifuge tube, but this is significantly more labor intensive when pooling multiple plates of probes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"ED40BFE0CABF11EB9F3A4DEE55234AE7","id":"47734","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-20","unit":10}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2em2l","text":"Preparation of Pooled Probe Library","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":35}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3ob7h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aqidf","text":"When pooling probes together to form the pooled probe library, the concentration of each individual padlock probe is normalized to the same concentration.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e8jbh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"77hmd","text":"To implement this, the volume pooled together from each individual gene pool should be proportional to the number of probes in that pool.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"e6il8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cfqn1","text":"As an example, if there are three transcripts in the library, gene A with 16 probes, gene B with 10 probes, and gene C with 14 probes, 160 μL from the gene A pool, 100 μL from the gene B pool, and 140 μL from the gene C pool are mixed together. If the probes were ordered at 200 μM each probe, the per-probe concentration in the gene A pool is 200/16 μM, in the gene B pool is 200/10 μM, and in the gene C pool is 200/14 μM. By taking an amount proportional to the number of probes in that pool, the variable per-probe concentrations are compensated for, and the final per-probe concentrations are all the same (in this case, 5 μM each; computed by 200/16 μM * 160 μL / (160 + 100 + 140 μL)).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"93e7e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cq5g8","text":"Pool proportional volumes of probes together (scaling up or down in volume) into a 50 mL tube, mix, and aliquot the final pooled probe libraries into microcentrifuge tubes. Typically, (10 μL x # of probes) is a reasonable volume to take from for each individual probe pool.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"284pt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ftnec","text":"Store individual probe pools and pooled probe libraries at  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":59,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"error_temperature":false,"guid":"10544540CABD11EB9F3A4DEE55234AE7","id":"47735","label":"","scientificNotation":false,"temperature":"-20","unit":10}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7npoe","text":"Worked Example of Probe Generation on Example Dataset","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":53}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3bc95","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5it2a","text":"In this worked example, the user will generate probes for three human genes, AKT1, CDK7, and KRT17, using a pre-prepared genelist and Genbank format files.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bmclt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5tl6q","text":"The results can be compared to reference results to confirm that the probe generation code is working correctly.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"gnra","text":"Environment Setup","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"die5l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"li0g","text":"Follow Step 1 to set up BLAST+ 2.2.26 and MATLAB/System path variables.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5976s","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dc76h","text":"Download Human RefSeq reference, and build BLAST database from humanrefseq.fna. Save BLAST database files in working directory (referred to as working_directory/ below).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"brdmo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"efvp2","text":"Download code from GitHub (https://github.com/anusinha/TargetedExSeqProbeGen) and save to working directory.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":27,"length":49}],"data":[]},{"key":"f53m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8a4uk","text":"Copy example_genbank.gb and example_genelist.xlsx from working_directory/example/example_input/ to working_directory/.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"DD3B10F7D90B11EBA3C50A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/anusinha/TargetedExSeqProbeGen"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"310jr","text":"Generating Homology Regions","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eu8lv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"abqn8","text":"Open Targeted_ExSeq_ProbeGeneration_Homology.m.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bp15r","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"eu205","text":"Set the following variables to the following values in the user input section:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"976ue","text":"genelist_spreadsheet = 'example_genelist.xlsx'","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7gl65","text":"genbank_sequences = 'example_genbank.gb'","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cp3i6","text":"refseq_database = 'humanrefseq.fna'","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2p1ke","text":"homology_regions_output = 'HomologyRegions'","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9frrh","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3v5sh","text":"Do not change any of the optional parameters.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2kd16","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cl9v0","text":"Run the MATLAB script, section by section. Updates will be printed to the console, and the output homology regions will be saved in working_directory/HomologyRegions/.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"85ao2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8ssa3","text":"The output files should match those in working_directory/example/example_output/HomologyRegionsExample/.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8oahn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"45er","text":"If there are slight discrepancies in the homology regions, this may result from slight differences in the current reference human transcriptome relative to the version used when generating the example data.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bkpht","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dt8t4","text":"The expected run time is \u003c 10 minutes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
